task.taskName: Model a Battery Biased CE Transistor

construction: Create a model for the battery-bias transistor amp shown in the schematic.  Nodes for the signal generator have been constructed already.  The resistor is 1000 ohms. Assume the base battery is 0.71 volts and the collector battery is 15 volts.  For the transistor, assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7 volts, and the resistance of the BE junction when forward biased is 100 ohms.  Finish the model and view the graph of the output voltage, that is, the voltage at the collector.
incremental: A battery-bias transistor amp is shown in the schematic.  Nodes for the signal generator have been constructed already.  Assume the base battery is 0.71 volts and the collector battery is 15 volts. For the transistor, assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7 volts, and the resistance of the BE junction when forward biased is 100 ohms.
execution: A battery-bias transistor amp is shown in the schematic.  Nodes for the signal generator have been constructed already.  Assume the base battery is 0.71 volts and the collector battery is 15 volts. For the transistor, assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7 volts, and the resistance of the BE junction when forward biased is 100 ohms.
waveform: A battery-bias transistor amp is shown in the schematic.  Nodes for the signal generator have been constructed already.  Assume the base battery is 0.71 volts and the collector battery is 15 volts. For the transistor, assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7 volts, and the resistance of the BE junction when forward biased is 100 ohms.

givenModelNodes.name: I out of collector
givenModelNodes.description: Current out of collector of transistor
givenModelNodes.explanation: As usually, the collector current is beta times the base current.

givenModelNodes.name: V across RL
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage drop across collector load resistor
givenModelNodes.explanation: Ohm's law, assuming current flows clockwise around the right loop.

givenModelNodes.name: R of BE junction
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of BE when forward biased

givenModelNodes.name: I out of base
givenModelNodes.description: Current out of base including both signal and bias
givenModelNodes.explanation: To calculate the current out of the base, just use Ohm's law and the resistance of the BE junction.  However, because the current flows counter clockwise around the left loop, the current out of the base will be positive, but the voltage at the base is negative.

givenModelNodes.name: V at base
givenModelNodes.explanation: You can use Kirchhoff's voltage law around the loop that has the voltage source in it.  Watch your signs.

schemas.name: CE Transistor Behavior
schemas.nodes: id9, id10, id17, id15, id19, id2, id18
